webTitle: Galloping horse by Eadweard Muybridge

fields.standfirst: In 1872, the former governor of California Leland Stanford, a race-horse owner, hired Eadweard Muybridge to undertake some photographic studies. Stanford had reputedly taken a bet on whether all four of a racehorse's hooves are off the ground simultaneously.  On 15 June 1878, Muybridge set up a line of cameras with tripwires, each of which would trigger a picture for a split second as the horse ran past. The results, as shown in this plate, settled the debate
fields.headline: Galloping horse by Eadweard Muybridge
fields.trailText: On 15 June 1878, Eadweard Muybridge set up a line of cameras with tripwires, each of which would trigger a picture for a split second as the horse ran past. This settled a popular debate of the time that all four of a racehorse's hooves are off the ground simultaneously

webTitle: Google launches giant balloon powered internet in New Zealand - video

fields.standfirst: Google launches giant balloons over New Zealand's south Island, carrying computer equipment that can create a high-speed internet infrastructure. Codenamed 'project loon', the helium filled balloons carry antennae, computers, batteries and navigational equipment, collecting power from solar panels that dangle below. Each can provide internet coverage over an area of 1200 square kilometres. The project intends to help remote areas across the world access internet coverage

webTitle: Daniel Love: 200 Hours

fields.standfirst:
Daniel Love, a British teacher in New York, documented his daily commute between Astoria and the end of 25th Street. 'I focus on trying to find a sense of solitude or quiet in one of the busiest places in the world,' he says. 'It's surprising how you can find tiny pieces of the puzzle that feel still as they bask in shifting light.' His title, 200 Hours, refers to the cumulative time of the commute.

tags.bio: Rupert Neate is a reporter. He was shortlisted for Reporter of the Year at the 2012 British Press Awards and the British Journalism Awards for his investigation that led to Liam Fox's resignation as defence secretary. He joined the Guardian in 2011 from the Daily Telegraph, were he worked for four years as City Diary editor and telecoms and technology correspondent. He was named Student Journalist of the Year at the Guardian Student Media Awards in 2006.

tags.bio: James Richardson hosts guardian.co.uk's football podcast Football Weekly. He was previously the host of the legendary Channel 4 show Football Italia.

Ben is guardian.co.uk's senior sports producer, looking after the Football Weekly podcast. He joined the Guardian in 2006, having previously worked for Channel 4 News and LBC radio in London. He's won two Sony awards for the Media Talk podcast, none for Football Weekly, and still hasn't written his best-selling book about an overweight cat

Paul Doyle is the
chief football writer for guardian.co.uk
Fernando Duarte is the UK Correspondent for O Globo, a Brazilian daily newspaper based in Rio, and also a provider of sporadic banter on Football Weekly
